dt: {bc}a salt or ester of any of various thio acids and especially C{inf}3{/inf}H{inf}6{/inf}OS{inf}2{/inf}

et: borrowed from French, from ({it}acide{/it}) {it}xanthique{/it} "any of various thio acids" (from Greek {it}xanthós{/it} "yellow" + French {it}-ique{/it} {et_link|-ic:1|-ic:1}) + {it}-ate{/it} {et_link|-ate:1|-ate:1} {ma}{mat|xantho-|}{/ma}

The discoverer of what is now known as xanthic acid, of which xanthate is the salt, was the Danish chemist William Christopher Zeise (1789-1847). (His name is conventionally given in English form; one branch of the Zeise family, which originated in Silesia, established itself in Denmark in the 17th century.) In the earliest published description of the acid and its salts ("Sur l'Acide hydro-xanthique, avec quelques-uns de ses produits et ses combinaisons," {it}Annales de chimie et de physique,{/it} tome 21ième [1821], pp. 160-178), Zeise named the radical of the presumed acid {it}xanthogène{/it} ("… parce qu'il forme des combinaisons de couleur jaune avec quelques métaux" - "because it forms yellow compounds with certain metals"). He called the acid itself {it}acide hydro-xanthique{/it} and the salts {it}hydro-xanthates.{/it} In a longer Danish version of the article, published later ("Xanthogensyren med nogle af dens producter og foreninger," {it}Det Kongelige Danske Videnskabernes Selskabs naturvidenskabeglige eg matematiske afhandlinger,{/it} förste deel [1824], pp. 219-76), the equivalent terms are {it}Xanthogen, Xanthogensyre,{/it} and {it}Xanthogensyresalte.{/it}
shortdef: a salt or ester of any of various thio acids and especially C3H6OS2

dt: {bc}a salt or ester of any of various thio acids and especially C{inf}3{/inf}H{inf}6{/inf}OS{inf}2{/inf}

et: borrowed from French, from ({it}acide{/it}) {it}xanthique{/it} "any of various thio acids" (from Greek {it}xanthós{/it} "yellow" + French {it}-ique{/it} {et_link|-ic:1|-ic:1}) + {it}-ate{/it} {et_link|-ate:1|-ate:1} {ma}{mat|xantho-|}{/ma}

The discoverer of what is now known as xanthic acid, of which xanthate is the salt, was the Danish chemist William Christopher Zeise (1789-1847). (His name is conventionally given in English form; one branch of the Zeise family, which originated in Silesia, established itself in Denmark in the 17th century.) In the earliest published description of the acid and its salts ("Sur l'Acide hydro-xanthique, avec quelques-uns de ses produits et ses combinaisons," {it}Annales de chimie et de physique,{/it} tome 21ième [1821], pp. 160-178), Zeise named the radical of the presumed acid {it}xanthogène{/it} ("… parce qu'il forme des combinaisons de couleur jaune avec quelques métaux" - "because it forms yellow compounds with certain metals"). He called the acid itself {it}acide hydro-xanthique{/it} and the salts {it}hydro-xanthates.{/it} In a longer Danish version of the article, published later ("Xanthogensyren med nogle af dens producter og foreninger," {it}Det Kongelige Danske Videnskabernes Selskabs naturvidenskabeglige eg matematiske afhandlinger,{/it} förste deel [1824], pp. 219-76), the equivalent terms are {it}Xanthogen, Xanthogensyre,{/it} and {it}Xanthogensyresalte.{/it}
shortdef: a salt or ester of any of various thio acids and especially C3H6OS2

dt: {bc}a feebly basic compound C{inf}5{/inf}H{inf}4{/inf}N{inf}4{/inf}O{inf}2{/inf} that occurs especially in animal or plant tissue, is derived from guanine and hypoxanthine, and yields uric acid on oxidation
{bc}any of various derivatives of xanthine (such as methylxanthine)

et: borrowed from German {it}Xanthin,{/it} from {it}Xanth{/it}oxyd, an earlier name for the substance (borrowed from English {it}xanthic oxide{/it}; {it}xanthic{/it} from Greek {it}xanthós{/it} "yellow" + {et_link|-ic:1|-ic:1}) + {it}-in{/it} {et_link|-in:1|-in:1} {ma}{mat|xantho-|}{/ma}

The German name {it}Xanthin{/it} was apparently introduced by the German chemist Leopold Gmelin (1788-1853) in {it}Handbuch der Chemie,{/it} 4. Auflage, 5. Band (Heidelberg, 1852), p. 514. Gmelin thought the name {it}Xanthin{/it} was preferable to {it}Xanthoxyd,{/it} but hesitated to recommend it because {it}Xanthin{/it} was already in use for a yellow pigment found in the madder plant ("welcher Name vorzuziehen wäre, wenn nicht auch das Krappgelb so hiesse"). (Note that the name {it}Hypoxanthin{/it} had already been suggested for a substance from which xanthine is formed by oxidation—see {et_link|hypoxanthine|hypoxanthine}.) English {it}xanthic oxide{/it} was introduced by Geneva-born British physician Alexander Marcet (1770-1822) in {it}An Essay on the Chemical History and Medical Treatment of Calculous Disorders{/it} (London, 1817). Marcet explained the name of the substance, which he had obtained from a urinary calculus, as follows (p. 101): "The term {it}Xanthic Oxyd,{/it} from ξανθος {it}yellow,{/it} has occurred to me as an appropriate name, because it alludes to a striking, and probably characteristic property of the substance in question, (that of forming a lemon-coloured compound when acted upon by nitric acid,) and yet does not imply any systematic notion as to its composition."
shortdef: a feebly basic compound C5H4N4O2 that occurs especially in animal or plant tissue, is derived from guanine and hypoxanthine, and yields uric acid on oxidation; also : any of various derivatives of xanthine (such as methylxanthine)

dt: {bc}a feebly basic compound C{inf}5{/inf}H{inf}4{/inf}N{inf}4{/inf}O{inf}2{/inf} that occurs especially in animal or plant tissue, is derived from guanine and hypoxanthine, and yields uric acid on oxidation
{bc}any of various derivatives of xanthine (such as methylxanthine)

The German name {it}Xanthin{/it} was apparently introduced by the German chemist Leopold Gmelin (1788-1853) in {it}Handbuch der Chemie,{/it} 4. Auflage, 5. Band (Heidelberg, 1852), p. 514. Gmelin thought the name {it}Xanthin{/it} was preferable to {it}Xanthoxyd,{/it} but hesitated to recommend it because {it}Xanthin{/it} was already in use for a yellow pigment found in the madder plant ("welcher Name vorzuziehen wäre, wenn nicht auch das Krappgelb so hiesse"). (Note that the name {it}Hypoxanthin{/it} had already been suggested for a substance from which xanthine is formed by oxidation—see {et_link|hypoxanthine|hypoxanthine}.) English {it}xanthic oxide{/it} was introduced by Geneva-born British physician Alexander Marcet (1770-1822) in {it}An Essay on the Chemical History and Medical Treatment of Calculous Disorders{/it} (London, 1817). Marcet explained the name of the substance, which he had obtained from a urinary calculus, as follows (p. 101): "The term {it}Xanthic Oxyd,{/it} from ξανθος {it}yellow,{/it} has occurred to me as an appropriate name, because it alludes to a striking, and probably characteristic property of the substance in question, (that of forming a lemon-coloured compound when acted upon by nitric acid,) and yet does not imply any systematic notion as to its composition."

dt.t: {wi}Gen X{/wi} managed to stretch adolescence beyond all previous limits: Its members started becoming adults earlier and finished becoming adults later.
… {lsquo}The Blair Witch Project,{rsquo} a stealth blockbuster with clever Internet marketing and so much {wi}Gen-X{/wi} appeal that it's spooking Hollywood.

utxt.t: … only about 56 percent of high-school seniors in 2015 went out on dates; for Boomers and {wi}Gen Xers{/wi}, the number was about 85 percent.
Like many {wi}Gen-Xers{/wi}, I remember childhood as an uncomplicated time when the only thing you had to worry about was being home by dark.

dt: {bc}the generation of people born in the 1960s and 1970s

dt.t: If you're a member of {wi}Generation X{/wi}, chances are you may be feeling that {ldquo}Reality Bites{rdquo} when it comes to your retirement planning.
The younger portion of the network's 12-to-34-year-old target audience … exhibited different tastes and sensibilities from the post-baby boom {wi}Generation X{/wi}.

shortdef: the generation of people born in the 1960s and 1970s

dt.t: {wi}Gen X{/wi} managed to stretch adolescence beyond all previous limits: Its members started becoming adults earlier and finished becoming adults later.
… {lsquo}The Blair Witch Project,{rsquo} a stealth blockbuster with clever Internet marketing and so much {wi}Gen-X{/wi} appeal that it's spooking Hollywood.

utxt.t: … only about 56 percent of high-school seniors in 2015 went out on dates; for Boomers and {wi}Gen Xers{/wi}, the number was about 85 percent.
Like many {wi}Gen-Xers{/wi}, I remember childhood as an uncomplicated time when the only thing you had to worry about was being home by dark.

shortdef: generation x —often used before another noun —often hyphenated in such use
